story:
Winter Waite: Santa's Helpers.



For those who missed out on previous Winter Waite campaigns and for our fans , we bring you the 2020 Winter Waite edition of the deck, complete with elves and candy canes.

This 2020 edition is a more fun take on our previous Winter Waite editions. We hope to bring some merriment and good cheer to your holiday readings. 

Every card is revisited, recoloured, and redesigned with various things like candy canes, peppermint swirls and a whole host of various elves, complete with snazzy costumes and winter wear.

 

Peppermint Swirls and Candy Canes
 

The candy canes (Wands) and peppermint swirls (pentacles) ideas were something that Christine came up with early on, and we felt that now was the time to officially put the project together.

The year 2020 has been rough on everyone globally; with unrest, political division, a global pandemic, huge forest fires, tornadoes and now asteroids hurtling towards earth. It’s small wonder that some are actually making a beeline right for Christmas.

For many, the festive season is filled with happy childhood memories, get togethers and generally a more optimistic time of year.

Our aim is to put a smile on your face with our happy, whimsical elves doing wintery things.

 

The Specifics
 

What you get is this year's 2020 Edition of the Winter Waite Tarot . You will also get the deck at the lowest price this holiday season. On site our decks retail between 55-60 USD. Contributors will get the deck here for 45 USD. You can save some money and help bring this project to life. 

All rewards will be sent standard delivery. We hope to have this project completed for November, and sent out on December, but keep in mind that shipping delays may be possible due to the ongoing Covid-19 situation along with the winter holiday season’s usual influx of mail.

If the campaign is fully funded this deck will come with a full color box,

78 cards
120mm x 70mm in dimension.
No booklet but instead PDF will be made available online.

story:
Decadent Dreams is the collaborative child of Claudia Musikul and Lina Khatib, and will take place in April. 

Claudia is a multi-medium artist with a background in classical ballet, film making, and avant- garde art. 

Lina Khatib is a visual artist, focusing primarily on photography and filmmaking. Influenced by her studies in literature and art, Lina captures nostalgic moments with her work.

Thanks to the funds we've raised so far we were able to complete our last day of filming this past Thursday February 13th. We want to thank everyone who has donated so far for making this possible. As promised we are sharing some beautiful behind the scenes photos taken by Raleigh Gambino from the shoot to give you a sneak peak of the current film and show what we were able to accomplish so far with this fundraiser. 

Lina and Claudia have previously collaborated on their short film Enfleurage which is currently streaming on Amazon Prime. Stills from Enfleurage below. 

 

In 2019 they were commissioned by Kafn, a local LA coffee shop to create a mid century modern ad style photo series interpreting drinks off the menu as 1960s characters. 

Lina and Claudia have created their own separate self portrait series to showcase their individual style for this show, which culminates in the showing of their latest film together. The show is a representation of their strengths both as artists individually and as collaborators. 

In order to produce the show, they need your help to fund the following: 

  • $750 - finishing the short film
  • $1000 - printing and material costs
  • $1250 - venue and food/drink

 

This show is a bigger undertaking than the events they’ve previously produced together. They kept finding themselves thinking about the shows they’ve previously attended and wanted to create a communal experience for attendees. Being conscious of the sensory experience one has at an exhibit, and finding a way to push that even further. Claudia and Lina want guests to spend their evening at the show; enjoying the narrative work of their photography, latest film, and a live performance. 

They were able to do their first film Enfleurage thanks in part to a previous INDIEGOGO campaign. For every project they’ve done thus far they’ve put a substantial amount of their own money into the production to get it done but have also needed a little help from friends whether it’s through equipment loans, or donations on this platform. With every project they aim to make it better artistically and technically; in filmmaking this often means higher budgets. 

If you aren’t able to donate financially, there are other ways you can help them make this event happen: 

  • Donate alcohol! 
  • Offer an event space
  • Volunteer your time (inquire for more information)
  • Bring a friend or a date
  • Share this campaign with your family and friends! 

Thank you for taking time to consider our campaign, we hope to see you at the show!

story:
Welcome to the Garden of the Lost World

17 years in the making, this incredible secret garden on the edge of the Lost World Wilderness Area is now preparing to be shared with the world!!

Lets build Darren a compost toilet and an online platform.

We are looking at around $2000 to get Darren a compost toilet, website & tablet to launch his phenomenal landscape art into the world. 

  • $600 for a website and online platform to be built through Squarespace.
  • $400 for a tablet so Darren can communicate with the outside world.
  • $1000 to build a compost toilet for visitors and guests.

Another way of being.

For anyone who has had the pleasure of experiencing the deeply inspiring creative nourishment of the living, breathing organic art that is his life's' soul work... you'll be feeling excited to know there is something epic emerging out of The Garden of the Lost World at the turn of Darren's half century celebration!

Darren is a unique example of a human being who has chosen to return to the garden full-time to re-wild his soul and live in perpetual reciprocity with the land, as a custodian, caretaker and gatekeeper to the Garden of the Lost World.

This is an opportunity to thank Darren for his incredible artistry and contribute towards building him an online platform to share his next level wonderment with the world, whilst also building a compost toilet with a roof so guests can feel comfortable taking a poo with a forest view!

Thanks everyone! Darren is going to be stoked with the community support on this one!

story:
grantrehnberg.com

Thank you for visiting my fundraising campaign for The Family Connection, a memorial art installation in honor of my grandfather James Burton Rehnberg.  

We buried my Grandpa Jim one month ago.  

Baptist pastor, World War II veteran (218th Counter Intelligence Corps), preceded in death by Grandma Doris, his wife of sixty-five years.  

Five months ago, Grandpa Jim told me he is gay. 

Sitting over photos of my husband Bradford and I at our wedding, my ninety-year-old grandfather proudly celebrated “the balls it takes” to live openly.  He told me about the love of his life, Warren Johnson, a boy he played music with at church.  He told me God loves every part of us.  He told me he would trade places with me if he could.  He told me he loved me.  

I put picture of Bradford and me in his suit coat pocket and a red rose on his coffin.

The Family Connection examines my relationship with this complicated man.  

In order to mourn Grandpa Jim, I will create a memorial installation, a eulogy that directly links our paralleled experiences as gay men and members of the Rehnberg family.  It seeks to answer the following questions:

How do I process my feelings toward a man whose legacy of religious shame, sexual repression, and fear of one’s true self shaped my own path?  How do I reconcile my experience as a young, privileged, openly gay man with his?

The installation consists of two sections:

The Shrine- An assemblage of photos, mementos, and writings encircles a charcoal portrait of Jim drawn in honor of his high school graduation.   

Left as offerings to his memory, these objects function as artifacts from his ninety years of life.  Symbols of grandpa’s past intermingle with my possessions. Groom sculptures created for my wedding stand next to photos of Warren, Jim’s first love.  His war medallions dangle before candles and scattered red roses.  A pink light illuminates his army memorial flag.  A favorite leather vest hangs neatly off to one side.  

86 Nichols (or Mama’s Boy, Sissy)- An 8’ x 12’ replica of Grandpa Jim’s childhood home stands against a wall, luminous and imposing.  Upon entering this structure, participants view a short film in which I deconstruct a Bible my grandfather gave me as a child.  

The house looks storm weathered, a crumbling symbol of Grandpa Jim’s formative childhood.  Here, Jimmy, the baby of eleven siblings lived with his sternly religious mother, who once beat him for wearing his sister’s face powder.  His brothers called him Mama’s boy and sissy.  His father died early.  Built from reclaimed materials at a small scale, the structure feels fort-like, a temple of youth built from the remnants of the past.  Shafts of interior light slice through gaps in the siding.  Through a small glass door (alternative, wheelchair accessible door is available as well), a black room awaits viewers.  

* I based my design of 86 Nichols on a vintage paper Mache model that Grandpa Jim gave me before he passed away.*

Within this darkened, tomblike space, a short movie plays on a loop.  Set to Perfume Genius’ “Dark Parts,” this footage represents a private ritual.  Clothed only in a jockstrap, I rip and crumple the pages from a Bible Grandpa Jim gave me in kindergarten.  Eyes closed, my face revolves atop flannelgraph trees, the inverted seasons of life and death.  I dance on the paper wreckage of my grandfather’s legacy.  I embrace and exhibit my body, celebrating a sexual freedom Grandpa Jim never completely knew.  I exorcize my religious-based, shame-filled inheritance.    

 The Family Connection, named after the Sunday school curriculum my grandparents taught together, binds my grandfather’s queerness and personal identity up with mine.  It explores both our intimate bonds and vast disconnects.  It reconciles my heart to his.

Love to you.

-Grant

story:
Elephant Room Inc. is thrilled to announce our expansion beyond the borders of the Wabash Arts Corridor in the South Loop. Our current gallery will still serve as our main hub for now, but this next chapter will involve several unique spaces around Chicago to exhibit larger, more extensive shows by local, emerging artists exploring the allegorical elephant in the room. These spaces include R. Hanel Gallery in the West Loop and Frazier Studios in the Fulton Market district. This would not be possible without our amazing colleagues and friends at these locations.


We are excited to pursue these pop-up endeavors as it will allow us more freedom and exposure for our artists. We will show these exhibits in the same spirit as we have been; focusing on passionate emerging artists who are taking risks and weaving relevant messages into their work. Our current location at 704 S Wabash Avenue will continue to host exhibitions acting as another pop-up space.
In addition to the pop-ups we are interested in seeing some of our conversations with artists and other organizations come to fruition in the form of public art projects and educational workshops. This constant dialogue of artistic expression will provide greater exposure for Elephant's artists and projects. 


The transition will enable us to provide further services in Art Consulting for artists, gallerists, collectors, and interns. Such services include intern and gallerist employment placement, artist career strategy and professional planning, and private and public collection development. Kimberly Leja Atwood's vast network and sincere dedication to the Chicagoland arts community are invaluable resources to anyone seeking career development in the field. 
As we approach our 5 year anniversary this November, we are excited about the gallery’s professional trajectory and the participating artists and curators in 2015. Some of the artists we’ll be working with next year include Sentrock, Andy Bellomo, Lewis Taylor, Will Fitzpatrick, Abraham, Cydney Lewis, Nicholas Barron and Jennifer Cronin.


Where will your money go? Your funds will be used to host the pop-up exhibitions around the city, to develop our Intern Placement Program so that more artists and students interested may utilize the program’s opportunities, and to help us pursue public art endeavors including workshops and lectures for the community. 

We are excited for this opportunity to expand our contemporary art conversations to broader communities in Chicago. With this more diverse audience in mind, Elephant Room will continue to bring local emerging artists to the forefront so they can been seen, celebrated and supported. 


Please help us reach these goals and expand our arts community with a financial investment. We sincerely appreciate your support of our mission and the artists we represent.

story:
Classrooms into Studios

By nature, kids are creative beings.  And yet, once they get to school, we seem to try really hard to drill and test that creativity out of them.  Young Audiences wants to change that.  We bring real, live, breathing, professional artists into schools to work directly with children.  Our artists transform a classroom into a studio and foster an environment of healthy risk-taking and creativity.  And it works! 

Young Audiences of Northern California has been transforming classrooms into studios and cafeterias into concert halls since 1958.  We are experts at integrating the arts--dance, music, theater, and visual arts--with subjects like math, science, and language arts, and when we do that, learning comes to life for kids!  


Now we need your help.  Over the past 10 years, funding for the arts in schools has been decimated.  In the San Francisco Bay Area--home to the creative thinking behind Google, Apple, Levi-Strauss, Zappos, and Pinterest--more than 50% of our schools fail to offer a single visual arts class.  And more than a third of our schools offer no music classes.  At all.  How can we foster creativity in our children when we don't give them a chance to make art in schools?  You can help to change this by supporting our "Classrooms into Studios" campaign.

When you help us reach our goal of $20,000, we will be able to bring art to life for 2,000 Bay Area students. 

And, if we reach our s--t--r--e--t--c--h goal of $30,000, we will be able to transform more than 150 Bay Area classrooms into studios, which means reaching 3,000 kids!  Who knows what next great thing will be conceived by a creative kid in one of those classrooms?  It's exciting to think about, isn't it?  We hope you will want to join the fun by becoming part of our campaign!

Our essential arts programs are enthusiastically supported by national, state and local leaders, school district personnel, teachers, parents, artists, foundations, businesses and people just like you--people who care about kids and creativity. 

Why us?

Young Audiences of Northern California (YANC) is the Bay Area’s premier provider of arts education services. Since 1958, Young Audiences has been connecting students with practicing, professional artists for artistically excellent and educationally effective art programming.  Our team provides all the support and training that professional artists need to help them make their art forms accessible to kids.  From how to deal with a reluctant 8th grader to how to engage a busy teacher, there aren't many challenges that we haven't faced ourselves and aren't ready to handle. 

Over the past three years, we have gone through dramatic organizational change and are rebuilding stronger than ever!  Last year, our 54 teaching artists worked in all four arts disciplines—music, theater, visual art, and dance—and created arts experiences of performance demonstrations and long-term, hands-on residencies. Last year, we reached 23,000 students in grades K-12 across the 9 counties of the Bay Area who otherwise would not have had these arts opportunities.  

Young Audiences of Northern California is proud to work with some of the finest artists in the Bay Area.  Among our roster of artists are National Endowment for the Arts fellows, Grammy nominees, and national touring performers. We partner with and support community artists in all art disciplines who are both exceptional practitioners of their art forms and skilled educators.

Whether you have $10 or $10,000 to give, your gift will come alive in the hearts and minds of our future artists, thinkers and scholars. And our business model allows for incremental growth: the more money we raise, the more kids we can serve!

Here is how the costs break down for our $30,000 stretch goal:

  • Fees paid to Artists:                                                 $ 8,000
  • Art Materials:                                                             $ 1,500
  • Artist recruitment and training:                                 $ 7,500
  • Insurance:                                                                 $ 2,000
  • Planning / Coordination with Schools:                      $ 5,500
  • Travel to Schools:                                                     $    500
  • Postage / Printing:                                                    $    500
  • Accounting / Bookkeeping:                                       $ 2,400
  • IndieGoGo Fee:                                                         $ 1,200
  • IndieGoGo Credit Card Fees:                                   $    900


Other Ways You Can Help

Maybe you just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help.

  • Please share this campaign with your friends, neighbors, schools, artists--anyone! Spreading the word helps, we promise! 


And that’s all there is to it. 

Except to say: THANK YOU!!!

Insurance:                                                                 $ 2,000
Planning / Coordination with Schools:                      $ 5,500

Travel to Schools:                                                     $    500
Postage / Printing:                                                    $    500

Accounting / Bookkeeping:                                       $ 2,400
IndieGoGo Fee:                                                         $ 1,200
IndieGoGo Credit Card Fees:                                   $    900


Other Ways You Can Help
Maybe you just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help. Please share this campaign with your friends, neighbors, schools, artists--anyone! Spreading the word helps, we promise! And that’s all there is to it. Except to say: THANK YOU!!!

story:
Short Summary

We are Vancouver-based Sheree Plett (singer songwriter) and Shari-Anne Vis (visual artist) who are old friends and have decided to go on an adventure and make a children's book! Inspired by recently becoming mothers ourselves, this creative project is meaningful and personal.  Sheree created an album of original lullabies for her son, Henry, and then asked Shari-Anne if she would illustrate one of her songs, Times Two. 

This old-fashioned, hardbound book features hand-made, watercolor paintings: raccoons fly to the moon and back, wear sweaters and swim goggles, float on the sea while watching clouds; their adventures all express how limitless our love is for our little ones. This book is especially for infants and toddlers, but could really be for any dearly loved people in our lives.

Here is a glimpse into our little book:

"I love you right up to the moon, then back again, times two. As wide as I can stretch my arms, as tall as I can reach, I love you, I love you, times two."

This book will include a free download of the song, Times Two!

By contributing to our campaign, you would enable us to print many copies so that we can share this book not only with our community but yours as well! 

What We Need & What You Get

We need $4800 to print 1000 hardbound books with 24 text pages.  We are excited to be getting them printed locally, in Canada, and would be so grateful for your contributions!

We have amazing perks that we will offer you to honour your generosity! These can include your very own copy of the book, Times Two, personally inscribed, as well as a song written personally by Sheree Plett.  Please see below for more details!

Even if we do not reach our goal, the funds we do receive will all go towards the cost of printing which will be so helpful!

The Impact

We are excited to sell our book in independent bookstores and through community events, but we are also excited to donate our book to those in our community who may have less access to beautiful children's literature.

Other Ways You Can Help

Thank you for considering our project! Please feel free to share our campaign with your friends and family using the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
A Little About Me...


My name is Scarlet Sinclair and I am a native NYC artist. I have been drawing since I was a little girl and have attended multiple art schools from LaGuardia High School (anyone hear of Fame?) to Pratt Institute where I earned my BFA. I have been drawing, painting, sculpting, taking photos, costuming, dancing and creating all kinds of art my entire life. 

For about 4 years, I was a part of the NYC burlesque scene performing and creating stage shows all over the city. This lead me down a glamourous and glittery path which in the end, helped me find my way right back to my roots: drawing. 

Going back to the simpler side of my creativity helped me realize that my next chapter would be to explore tattooing. I've been a tattoo collector for about 13 years and have always been in love with it as an art form. The lightbulb finally went off: it was the perfect medium for my art. I now own my own tattoo shop, Tattoo Ritual, in Farmingdale, NY and am constantly looking for ways to push myself and evolve as an artist.

Famous for films such as Labyrinth and The Dark Crystal and his numerous faerie art books (Good Faeries/Bad Faeries, the Lady Cottington series, etc), Brian Froud has shown the world what a true visionary he is. I've been a huge fan for years and recently discovered that he was offering a Master Drawing Class this summer at Belcastel in Aveyron, France. I knew this was a once in a lifetime opportunity. Who knows if he'll ever offer another workshop such as this again. Either way, I'm not willing to pass this up to wait and find out! 

Not only would it be a dream come true to learn from one of my all-time personal heroes, being held in such a stunning and historic setting such as a 9th C. medieval fortress in the French countryside is straight out of a storybook. Otherworldly. Just like his art! I knew it was something I had to make happen. 

I truly believe that this trip will not only enrich my general life experience but give me new tools, new eyes and enough inspiration to last a lifetime. It will enhance my abilities as an illustrator and ultimately as a tattooer. I can't wait to see the things I'm going to draw and tattoo upon my return! 


What's Needed & What You Get...

The Master Class is going to be held August 4-11 and to secure my spot, I am required to pay for the Class and Lodging fees by April 1st. (approximately $2000, as the price is set in Euros). Once that is secured I will need to book roundtrip airfare from NYC to Dublin (approx. $1200) and then another roundtrip ticket from Dublin to Rodez, France (approx. $200). I am also projecting costs for food, fees, taxes and other unforeseen travel expenses that may arise. 

If you decide to make a contribution, I plan to start a blog just for this specific adventure so that I can share my experience with you! I want you to see exactly what your generosity is going towards. 

http://scarlettattoos.tumblr.com/

I'm also planning to offer some incentives to make your involvement that much more enticing! For your review to the right --->

You'll know you've supported the arts, helped me become better at my craft and have also assisted in making a dream come true for me.

Other Ways You Can Help This Gypsy!

Spread the word! Check out my links to learn more about me and my world. And use the share tools provided by IndieGoGo to get other folks in-the-know.


I'll be forever indebted!

xoxo

Scarlet


http://www.scarlettattoos.com

http://www.facebook.com/pages/Tattoo-Ritual/164...

http://www.worldoffroud.com

http://www.chateaubelcastel.com


Special thanks to Orlando Ferreyra for editing my video and to Sangara for the dreamy soundtrack! <3

story:
About Under 91

In 2012, a group of community members put together a public art project that temporarily lit up a couple of these underpasses. Now we're ready to put up permanent, colorful installations to brighten up the area and invite people to cross the border between the New Haven communities of Fair Haven & East Rock. 

Find out more about Under 91, including the design that was selected, by visiting our website. 

Fundraising

To install the first mural we need to raise $15,000. We've raised about $9,000 (in online and offline donations) and are in the final stretch before we start painting. Help us make our goal! 

Donations will cover costs associated with materials, artist compensation, community involvement, and future maintenance & upkeep.  Under 91 has been and will continue to be coordinated on a purely volunteer basis. The project is overseen by the Urban Resources Initiative. 

Any money left over will be used to support future murals underneath I-91 in New Haven.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn't mean they can’t help:

  • Follow us on facebook - we'll be posting meetings and events as we prepare to kick off the painting!

story:
Short Summary

We are a camp of artists, chefs, caterers, DJs and mixologists who have come together to create all the best of Fire and Ice for Burning Flipside. We will bring the artistic talents we have exhibited around the world to sculpt ice in performance for our fellow Flipizens. We will create a DJ stand out of Ice for our talented DJs to spin their fine tunes on. Our fabulous shot ladies will pour elixers over special Ice shot slides to the delight of all and we will provide our World Famous Flamethrower Pizza for our guests enjoyment.

What We Need & What You Get

We need your help to provide ice blocks for sculptures and gas for the freezer truck to keep our sculpting medium sub zero until performance time. By helping to fund these items you may enjoy perks ranging from our eternal gratitude to a steak dinner cooked by our award winning Chef/Sculptor in the company of the Fire and Ice camp. This year our camp is also bringing a Jellyfish installation, a brewmaster, CREATE - our art installation using ALL of the Flipside ticket envelopes and many more art installations for your enjoyment. See our website to view some of the amazing works created by our Master Ice Artist.  www.wickedice.com   And please like our Facebook page for more details - https://www.facebook.com/WickedIceAustin

The Impact

This is our third year for Fire and Ice camp at Burning Flipside and we intend to be a positive addition to the community by exhibiting the burning principles and radically adding to the event. Your support will help us attain these goals.

Other Ways You Can Help

Contribute if you can and receive one of our cool perks. If you are unable to contribute, please help let others know about our campaign, or just share a positive thought with some one while thinking of us. Enrich your life in unexpected ways and share your experiences. Namaste.

story:
SELECTED to be part of the Bronx River Art Center's "Virtual/Monumental" exhibit.

Opening Reception: Saturday, August 11th.

 

THE STORY

The Bronx River Art Center put out an open call for submissions for an exhibit called "Virtual/Monumental", a group of works to be experienced throughout the West Farms neighborhood using iPhones, iPads, and other mobile devices.  Maria and Nate - classmates from NYU, great friends, and oft-collaborators - talked it through: "We should submit a project!"

We did some research about the neighborhood and found out about the Old West Farms Soldiers' Cemetery, an almost 200-year-old cemetery nestled in between project houses and a church, that is the home to 40 local soldiers who fought in the War of 1812, Spanish-American War, Civil War, and World War I.  We were mesmerized by the intimate nature of the cemetery and the stories of the men buried there.  We thought a lot about the ritual, location, and meanings of burial, and how these pieces play into the sacrifices men and women of the Bronx, New York, and USA have been making as soldiers from the Revoltionary War through today, in Afghanistan.

We applied, crossed our fingers, and waited: soon enough, we were thrilled to learn we had been selected! 

 

THE CAMPAIGN

Our piece, A Play to Lay My Head, seeks to pay homage to the long line of sacrifices made by soldiers from the Bronx by setting each viewer onto an intimate journey throughout the cemetery.

The Bronx River Art Center is a modest organization, and one of the few arts organizations in the Bronx biting off way more than it can chew.  Therefore, we are looking to raise a small amount of funds to off-set the costs of the project that exceed the stipend we have been awarded.

We've been thrilled to work with three amazing collaborators on the project:

  • LOU GRUBER, our Cinematographer and Editor
  • BRIAN HASTERT and WILL SEEFRIED, our Performers

All funds raised will go to:

  • Paying Lou, Brian, and Will for their incredible work
  • Paying for the military costumes
  • Paying for props and other small equipment
  • Transportation (gas and tolls) to and from the cemetery while we made the piece

THE EVENT

Finally, we very much hope you can join us on Saturday, August 11th for the opening reception of "Virtual/Monumental" and to experience A Play to Lay My Head for yourself.  We are incredibly proud of the piece and want to share it with as many of our friends as possible.

  • Date: Saturday, August 11th
  • Time: Walking Tours (to take you to each of the six pieces in the show) are at 11am, 12:30pm, and 2:00pm
  • BBQ: There is also a BBQ from 12:00pm - 4:00pm
  • Location: 2064 Boston Post Road, Bronx, NY 10460 (our piece is specifically located at E. 180th St. and Bryant Ave., Bronx NY)


QUESTIONS

If you have any questions, feel free to email us at nathanvkoch@gmail.com or mocerinomocerino@gmail.com.


Thank you for reading and you support of A Play to Lay My Head!

story:
Short Summary

Hello! HellooO!! As you may know, once a year a few thousand of the luckiest and funniest and most creative people among us gather in Black Rock City (BRC), in the Nevada Desert to share the love at Burning Man...no big deal, just some 70,000 people from all over the World. At Burning Man 2014, coming up in just a few days, we, the Vagabond Android Campers, have dedicated ourselves to sharing our Arabian Nights Art Car with the playa. Hailing from San Francisco, the car is undergoing a massive transformation to embrace this year's theme of Caravansary. Help us get there!


Art Car Transformation:

BEFORE:


AFTER:

This is what the art car will look like, with a little love from you!


What We Need & What You Get

Love has no price, but building this fantastic monstrosity does! Your donation will help us do the following: 

-Get the car to Black Rock City!

-Keep the car moving all week long, so we can share in the revelry on the playa!


The money will be spent in this order of priority:

  • Rental of the sound system : $2500--We have quite a few of extremely talented DJs in our camp, and want to share them with the Burning Man community!
  • Gas: $1000 (the more money, the more music on the Playa)
  • Customization of the art car: $1000--more scrilla=more kick-ass Arabian Nights!

    Risks & Challenges

    We can't do it without your support! 

      Other Ways You Can Help

      Even if you can't donate the cashola, help us spread the word!

      • Get the word out, and make some noise about our campaign. Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, Pinterest, LinkedIn, sign in your driveway, mailing a letter to your long-lost cousin, posters on a telephone pole, you name it!
      • Use the Indiegogo share tools! Indiegogo provides you with lots of nifty buttons that will share this campaign with your social circles!

story:
Who Am I ?

My name is Kayla Knadle. I am a self-employed artist. I work from home, and while commissions may be slow, it is the passion in my life. I am an artist of many different skills ranging from drawing, oil painting, watercolors, airbrushing, and even painting dolls as well as sculpting. I pride myself in my ability to paint quickly without losing quality of my work. I recently had an art exhibition at Wake the Dead Coffee House in San Marcos, TX, and I am currently looking to do more shows. I truly enjoy my work and I cannot imagine myself doing anything else with my life!


Long Story Short:

I would love to exchange my artwork for expensive dental bills to improve the quality of my life and continue making art.


Why do I need help?

When I went away to college, I had to get my braces taken off early as I could no longer afford them- they were nowhere near ready to be taken off, either. After recently graduating and moving to a new state, I lost my health insurance as I cannot be covered by my parents anymore. I am hoping to get insurance in this upcoming enrollment year through my fiancé, but right now I am stuck between a rock and a hard place as I need work done ASAP.

After my braces were taken off early, I was affixed with a permanent retainer that needed to be removed 3 years ago. In that time, the retainer has shifted my teeth as well as deteriorated my bone in my jaw. On top of that, bad genetics have left me with cavities and nearing the edge of needing a root canal. I do need at least one crown to be put on my tooth as soon as possible before the pain gets even worse. At this point, braces may even become medically necessary because of the deterioration.

I was given the pricing estimate of all the work that needs to be done, not including braces, of $4,000. I have done everything in my power to call every dentist, financing, carecredit, medical assistance program, etc and nothing could be done to reduce this bill. Even if I had Medicaid, the dentist wouldn’t accept it. My only option right now is to do one procedure at a time, out of pocket, and hope it isn’t too late before I can get everything fixed.


What will you get?

I am willing and eager to provide artwork for your support. I am very capable of working quickly and I can draw, paint, or create anything you would like, just drop me a note/email specifying what you are looking for and I can do my best. Sketches below contributions of $50 will be single character (or animal) with no or little background. Artwork for contributions above $50 may be talked about privately! Please, let me know if you are located out of the United States. I will need to speak to you about shipping costs.


·  $1 gets a personalized thank you for your support


·  $5 gets a personalized letter mailed to you


·  $10  gets a digital drawing + personalized letter mailed to you


·  $25 gets an original drawing + personalized letter mailed to you


·  $50 gets a watercolor painting + personalized letter mailed to you


·  $100 gets a woodblock drawing + personalized letter mailed to you


·  $200 gets a woodblock painting + personalized letter mailed to you


·  $300 gets a woodblock painting + watercolor painting + personalized letter


·  $600 gets an original oil painting smaller than 24” x 32”  + personalized letter mailed to you


·  $1,000 gets an original oil painting diptych of two 24” x34” panels  + personalized letter mailed to you


When will you receive your artwork?

I have work that is already completed and ready to be shipped, if you would like a piece please let me know and I can mail it out as soon as possible. If you see an existing piece that you really like but is sold let me know and I may be able to create something similar!

I will do my best to make sure that all work is completed within the order of the contributions. As I do artwork for a living, I will have to balance already existing commissions with indiegogo commissions. Because I will need dental work done, there may be a period of resting time between procedures as I’m sure I will be in a lot of pain. I promise you this: you will receive your artwork in under 6 months of the campaign ending. Small pieces under the $100 contribution mark will be completed  within a month after the campaign ends.  Larger, more intricate works will be discussed with you as they require more time. I hope to speak with you individually on any dates that are important to have your work done by (birthday, anniversaries, etc), so please do let me know. I ask for your patience and trust.


Please view my image gallery for example of perks and available paintings!


Thank you so much for reading and your support. Even if you cannot contribute, please feel free to spread the news. I appreciate your time,
Kayla
story_txt:
Who Am I ?

My name is Kayla Knadle. I am a self-employed artist. I work
from home, and while commissions may be slow, it is the passion in my life. I
am an artist of many different skills ranging from drawing, oil painting,
watercolors, airbrushing, and even painting dolls as well as sculpting. I pride
myself in my ability to paint quickly without losing quality of my work. I
recently had an art exhibition at Wake the Dead Coffee House in San Marcos, TX,
and I am currently looking to do more shows. I truly enjoy my work and I cannot
imagine myself doing anything else with my life!
Long Story Short:
I would love to exchange my artwork for expensive dental
bills to improve the quality of my life and continue making art.
Why do I need help?
When I went away to college, I had to get my braces taken
off early as I could no longer afford them- they were nowhere near ready to be
taken off, either. After recently graduating and moving to a new state, I lost
my health insurance as I cannot be covered by my parents anymore. I am hoping
to get insurance in this upcoming enrollment year through my fiancé, but right
now I am stuck between a rock and a hard place as I need work done ASAP.
After my braces were taken off early, I was affixed with a
permanent retainer that needed to be removed 3 years ago. In that time, the retainer has shifted my teeth as
well as deteriorated my bone in my jaw. On top of that, bad genetics have left
me with cavities and nearing the edge of needing a root canal. I do need at
least one crown to be put on my tooth as soon as possible before the pain gets
even worse. At this point, braces may even become medically necessary because
of the deterioration. 
I was given the pricing estimate of all the work that needs
to be done, not including braces, of $4,000. I have done everything in my power
to call every dentist, financing, carecredit, medical assistance program, etc
and nothing could be done to reduce this bill. Even if I had Medicaid, the
dentist wouldn’t accept it. My only option right now is to do one procedure at
a time, out of pocket, and hope it isn’t too late before I can get everything
fixed.
What will you get?
I am willing and eager to provide artwork for your support. I
am very capable of working quickly and I can draw, paint, or create anything
you would like, just drop me a note/email specifying what you are looking for
and I can do my best. Sketches below contributions of $50 will be single
character (or animal) with no or little background. Artwork for contributions
above $50 may be talked about privately! Please, let me know if you are located
out of the United States. I will need to speak to you about shipping costs.
· 
$1 gets a personalized thank you for your
support
· 
$5 gets a personalized letter mailed to you
 · 
$10  gets
a digital drawing + personalized letter mailed to you
· 
$25 gets an original drawing + personalized
letter mailed to you
· 
$50 gets a watercolor painting + personalized
letter mailed to you
· 
$100 gets a woodblock drawing + personalized
letter mailed to you
· 
$200 gets a woodblock painting + personalized
letter mailed to you
· 
$300 gets a woodblock painting + watercolor
painting + personalized letter
· 
$600 gets an original oil painting smaller than
24” x 32”  + personalized letter mailed
to you
· 
$1,000 gets an original oil painting diptych of
two 24” x34” panels  + personalized
letter mailed to you
When will you receive your artwork?
I have work that is already completed and ready to be
shipped, if you would like a piece please let me know and I can mail it out as
soon as possible. If you see an existing piece that you really like but is sold
let me know and I may be able to create something similar!
I will do my best to make sure that all work is completed
within the order of the contributions. As I do artwork for a living, I will
have to balance already existing commissions with indiegogo commissions.
Because I will need dental work done, there may be a period of resting time
between procedures as I’m sure I will be in a lot of pain. I promise you this:
you will receive your artwork in under 6 months of the campaign ending. Small pieces
under the $100 contribution mark will be completed  within a month after the campaign ends.  Larger, more intricate works will be discussed with you as they require more
time. I hope to speak with you individually on any dates that are important to
have your work done by (birthday, anniversaries, etc), so please do let me
know. I ask for your patience and trust.Please view my image gallery for example of perks and available paintings!
Thank you so much for reading and your support. Even if you
cannot contribute, please feel free to spread the news. I appreciate your time,Kayla

story:
The True You Project

The True You Project is dedicated to seeing people at their best and giving them a chance to see it for themselves. I'll be having life coaching conversations with 100 people so that they can (re)discover their true selves and taste what their life could be if they were to continue living from that place.  The essence that we discover in each call will become the inspiration for a work of art, resulting in 100 pieces.

It was through a year-long life coach training program that I rediscovered I wanted to be an artist.  Through coaching, I was able to reconnect with the essence of who I am, which provided me with the clarity and strength to see my fears and doubts as thoughts that simply weren't true. This fearlessness to pursue my dreams is what inspired this project and it's what I'm hoping to share with each individual who takes part in it. 

Through an hour and a half coaching conversation, people can see and own what makes them unique. For the people I've worked with so far, this has been a springboard into creating the life they dream about rather than they one they think they should be living.

Since words can only go so far in conveying the essence of a human being, I've decided to capture it through art.  The culmination of The True You project will be an Art Show in a gallery in Chelsea displaying all 100 works of those 100 individuals.  The Show is intended to be a celebration the amazing capacity human beings have for love.  And you're all invited!

What We Need & What You Get

This is a passion project of mine to take action toward creating the world I envision—a world of love and collaboration rather than fear and competition.  It’s an ultimate work of collaboration because I can’t make this project a reality without some outside support. Your donations will go to:

·       Renting the venue for the final show/experience

·       Supplies for creating the art

·       Food and drinks that will be provided at the show

·      Hiring assistance in putting the show together

·       Production and marketing costs

What you get in return for your donation

·       $10 – personalized thank you note featuring a work from the show

·       $25 – thank you note and a free ticket to the event

·       $100 – thank you note, free ticket, and a free life coaching call as part of the project

·       $250 – all of the above, plus you get to take home your personalized artwork

    The Impact

    What I’m offering people is an opportunity for love, connection, and transformation.  It’s not every day that a person has the opportunity to talk about their life with an outside, unbiased, nonjudgmental party, and the gift of listening and reflecting without judgment is priceless. 

    The outcome of each conversation is a work of art, but it’s really a reflection of an experience and the possibility of the life you've been dreaming about but may not have thought possible. 

      Other Ways You Can Help

      Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

      • Share on social media.
      • Share with friends and family.
      • Maybe's there a community bulletin board you post this on.
      • You may know someone looking for a personalized piece of art, who would be interested in being part of this project.
      • I'm looking for food and drink vendors to partner with.  You may know some great breweries or wineries.
      • If you've already participated in the project, you can share the value you got from it.

      Thank you <3

story:
My Story

I am an art therapist in Nelson, British Columbia and have recently been invited to present at the 2016 International Art Therapy Conference in Hong Kong.

This invitation comes as a great honour and works towards both the advocacy of the field of art therapy and the development of global community. At the conference I will present my thesis, where I facilitated an art therapy group with International High School students from various world regions including China, South Korea, Germany, France and Mexico. Findings revealed many benefits in supporting international students who face the challenges of living and studying in a host country. Through creative expression and social connection, the art group allowed international students a safe and supportive environment to explore and express aspects of personal and cultural identity, learn interpersonal skills, improve linguistic and cultural fluency, and enjoy the connection and creativity of the art group experience. Together, we recognized that art serves not only as a means of self-expression but as a language that has the power to transcend cultural and linguistic barriers.

This project will also take me to Taiwan, where I previously lived as an artist and educator. In Taiwan I learned Mandarin Chinese,  immersed myself in Taiwanese culture, and over the years cultivated a rich community of local and international friends. As a Mandarin speaker, the ability to serve the community in promoting mental health and wellness through the modality of art therapy for self-expression, personal growth, and healing is an amazingly personal and cross-cultural connection. 

Both my time as an ESL educator and as an art therapist has shown me the significance of helping to build the self-esteem and self-empowerment of those I interact with. It is in this spirit that, while in Taiwan I will offer a series of free art therapy workshops and hold several exhibitions to share my own therapeutic art journey with my community there.

While in Hong Kong I will also have the opportunity to further my training in Trauma-Informed Art Therapy through a 3-day certification program facilitated by an American art therapy pioneer. This training will equip me for future work with individuals and groups who have experienced trauma. This work has never been more important than at this time where many countries including Canada are welcoming refugees and immigrants from war-torn regions who require support in adapting to their new homes and in healing traumas incurred through their transitions.

Global community is really important to me. I am so grateful for the opportunity to share my passion and experiences through this project, and in doing so, continue to cultivate community, and expand my concept of ‘Home’.

Give and Receive

As a professional Art Therapist and a member of an international community in Taiwan and Hong Kong, I have accepted an important opportunity to:

  • Present my Art Therapy research thesis (about the benefits of a therapeutic art group with international high school students) at the 2016 International Art Therapy Conference in Hong Kong.
  • Complete Level 3 Trauma-Informed Art Therapy Certification in Hong Kong (with art therapy pioneer Dr. Cathy Malchiodi).

Your contribution will support me and my partner to complete this project. In Hong Kong I will complete the training, present my thesis at the conference, and cultivate connections with an international community of cutting edge Art Therapy pioneers. 

As the director of Avatar Computer and Technology, my partner/videogrpher will be a valued member of the Conference Volunteer Team to provide his technological expertise and support.

In addition we will spend time in Taiwan where I will be offering a series of free Art Therapy workshops to give individuals from both the local and international community an opportunity to experience first-hand the benefits of Art Therapy. My partner/videographer will video and photo document the project, and create a documentary which will be shared with contributors, participants, family and friends, and our local and international community.

Your contributions will cover our Basic Costs: 

  • $703 for Trauma-Informed Art Therapy Certification Level 3 with the renowned Dr. Cathy Malchiodi (in Hong Kong, May 21-23) ($703)
  • $500 each for Conference fees for presenting/participating at the 2016 International Conference on Art Therapy (in Hong Kong, May 27-29) ($500 x 2 = $1000)
  • $1100 each for round-trip flights from Nelson, B. C., to Taiwan ($1100 x 2 = $2200)
  • $270 each for round-trip flights from Taiwan to Hong Kong ($270 x 2 = $540)
In addition, your contributions will fund a series of Art Therapy Workshops in Taiwan for the local and international community:
  • 3 workshops accommodating 14 participants each at $25/participant (42 participants x $25 = $1050)
  • Art materials for the workshops at $6/person (42 participants x $6 = $252)
  • Workshop total cost: $1302
  • Total expenses: $5745 CAD

  • If we do not reach our entire campaign goal, we will use your contributions to fund the Trauma-Informed Art Therapy Training, and Conference fees. We want to prioritize education and advocacy of the field of Art Therapy.
  • In the event that we raise more than our campaign goal, surplus funds will be utilized to provide professional Art Therapy services to individuals and groups who have experienced trauma, or who are working to integrate themselves inter-culturally, such as with international students, immigrants and refugees.

The Perks for Contributors:

In gratitude for your contributions, we are offering a variety of perks, from original art postcards mailed from Taiwan or Hong Kong, handmade art cards and art prints, a Mandala Coloring Book, Computer Consultation Sessions with Avatar Computer and Technology, Mandarin Chinese Lessons, Art Therapy Workshops, and Original Paintings. All art is original by Laura Andrew. Please see the 'Perks' section for specifics.



As a way of giving back to the local and international community in Taiwan, I will do the following:

  • Share my Art Therapy training and experience by offering a series of Free Art Therapy workshops in Taiwan.
  • Create a documentary about this international art therapy project to raise awareness of the benefits of art therapy in promoting mental health and well-being.
  • Hold two Art Shows at the Lei Gallery and Chameleon Workshop to share my therapeutic art journey which unfolded throughout my two years training as an art therapist.
To see these non-profit Art Collectives in Taiwan, please follow the links below:
Chameleon Workshop Facebook Page
Lei Gallery Facebook Page
  • Additionally, upon returning home to Nelson, BC, we will share our experience and documentary through a social action event at the Kuentai Art Therapy Institute. Details to follow.

The Impact

The impacts of this project will be felt on three levels: Individual, Community and Global.

Individual: To me, Art Therapy is about empowerment and healing at the personal level. At any age or stage in one's life, Art Therapy can be a used to tell one's story, and as a tool for self-expression, personal growth and insight. As an Art Therapist, I am passionate about advocating for the field of Art Therapy. This means that in addition to offering Art Therapy services to individuals and groups, I also embrace opportunities to present at conferences, offer workshops, and continue my professional development. 

Community: This project is about cultivating community on the local, international and global levels. Through participating in international Art Therapy training and conferences, and providing hand-on art therapy experience for individuals in Taiwan, international community is cultivated, and the benefits of the therapeutic arts process are shared more widely. 

Global: Our videographer will video document the project and create a documentary about the experience which will be shared locally and globally. We hope that the knowledge and experience gained from this project will benefit all those involved.

The 2016 International Conference on Art Therapy in Hong Kong:

The Conference will feature keynote speakers as well as more than 20 other cutting-edge art therapy pioneers from 15 countries, delivering workshops and papers on the use of art therapy in different cultures and contexts. In view of the urgent need for assistance by children and adolescents with special educational needs and people who have experienced trauma, the theme of the Conference will focus on these populations of people in need.

The 2016 International Conference on Art Therapy is organized by a group of passionate and professional art therapists, clinical psychologists and social workers. All surplus of this Conference will be donated to Psycho-Art Therapy Association, a team of volunteers using art therapy to help people in need in China, Hong Kong, Nepal, Cambodia and Myanmar.

For more information, please see the links below:

http://www.hkicp.org/ICAT/2016/index.php#

http://www.hkicp.org/en/index.php


What is Art Therapy?

Art Therapy is a form of Expressive Arts Therapy that uses the creative process of making art within a therapeutic relationship, to improve a person's physical, emotional, and mental well-being. As Art Therapists we believe that the creative process is inherently healing and life-enhancing. 
For more information, see this article by Cathy Malchiodi: What is Art Therapy?

"But I'm not an Artist!"

A common misconception that I often hear in my work is that one needs to be an artist to enjoy the benefits of Art Therapy. The intention of using art as a tool for self-expression is that through the use of color, line, metaphor and imagery, we can by-pass the conscious mind and express ourselves in ways that are sometimes not possible through verbal language.


Other Ways You Can Help

We deeply appreciate your support!  Even if you cannot contribute to this project you can join us by sharing this campaign with friends via social media, email, and word of mouth. 

Share the campaign link: https://igg.me/at/arttherapy-hongkong-taiwan

Follow us on Facebook, Click: HERE

We are grateful for your contribution to our project!

story:
What is this Garbage?

Wow, not one to mince words are you? Well, your favorite McIlmail has had an idea for an art project and he has been sitting on plans for about a year now. It is a mixed media series in two parts: 

1) The first focuses on the relationship between American Generations, specifically between Baby Boomers and the painfully named Millenials (an atrocious word I know) 

2) The second portion of the series would be an exploration of gender and how this shapes what it means "to be an American"

Vague? Maybe. Important? I wouldn't be trying to persuade you for help if I didn't think so! 

You Have a Job, What Do You Need My Pennies for?

I am so glad you asked. While I pay back student loans by selling my organs on the black market, your donation would help to:

  • Pay for gas to and from interviews and photo sessions
  • Get the neccesary equipment for shooting photos and video
  • Print and frame the images 
  • Feed anyone who is willing to help with production
  • And, if all goes well, have a small gallery showing--at which I would hope to see every last one of you guys

Why Should I Donate to some Queer Arts and Crafts Project?

So, maybe its not your cup of tea, fair enough. Maybe you aren't very interested in gender identity topics, hell maybe you aren't even American. But I think culture and identity are extremely important to everyone. These are my cultures and while I have never really felt "American" or "Gay," I have always wanted to learn. I want to learn from as many of you as I can and mold those different perspectives into a piece of art that can reflect the diversity and depth of these identites.


Wrap it Up Kid

Complete honesty, I have no delusions of raising this amount of money (I know everyone says that, but its true). Any amount would make this goal that much more possible. While I may have once made fun of myself for doing this, now I know sometimes you just have to ask for help. I'm sure many of you are riddled with loans like I am, so if you can't donate it would mean more than you know if you just share this page with friends, family, and any lover of underdog amateur art experiments. Thanks!
story_txt:
What is this Garbage?Wow, not one to mince words are you? Well, your favorite McIlmail has had an idea for an art project and he has been sitting on plans for about a year now. It is a mixed media series in two parts: 1) The first focuses on the relationship between American Generations, specifically between Baby Boomers and the painfully named Millenials (an atrocious word I know) 2) The second portion of the series would be an exploration of gender and how this shapes what it means "to be an American"Vague? Maybe. Important? I wouldn't be trying to persuade you for help if I didn't think so! You Have a Job, What Do You Need My Pennies for?I am so glad you asked. While I pay back student loans by selling my organs on the black market, your donation would help to:
Pay for gas to and from interviews and photo sessions
Get the neccesary equipment for shooting photos and video
Print and frame the images 
Feed anyone who is willing to help with production
And, if all goes well, have a small gallery showing--at which I would hope to see every last one of you guys
Why Should I Donate to some Queer Arts and Crafts Project?So, maybe its not your cup of tea, fair enough. Maybe you aren't very interested in gender identity topics, hell maybe you aren't even American. But I think culture and identity are extremely important to everyone. These are my cultures and while I have never really felt "American" or "Gay," I have always wanted to learn. I want to learn from as many of you as I can and mold those different perspectives into a piece of art that can reflect the diversity and depth of these identites.
Wrap it Up Kid
Complete honesty, I have no delusions of raising this amount of money (I know everyone says that, but its true). Any amount would make this goal that much more possible. While I may have once made fun of myself for doing this, now I know sometimes you just have to ask for help. I'm sure many of you are riddled with loans like I am, so if you can't donate it would mean more than you know if you just share this page with friends, family, and any lover of underdog amateur art experiments. Thanks!

story:
THE MILLENNIAL TRAINS PROJECT (MTP) is a 501(c)3 non-profit organization that leads crowd-funded transcontinental train journeys for diverse groups of young innovators (and virtual audiences) to explore America's new frontiers.

To get on board, applicants design a project to advance across the communities where our train stops and then race to be among the first 15 applicants on their selected train journey to reach their $5,000 crowdfunding goal. To learn more about the 2016 journeys click here. The applicant's project is described below.

THE PROJECT

A curated digital storytelling platform highlighting the ways artists, communities, and creative thinkers are transforming under-resourced public spaces into meaningful places of culture, expression, inquiry, and connection.


THE INSPIRATION

What do Uncommon Spaces look like? They are everyday public spaces that have been transformed into multi-faceted cultural centers through a combination of community outreach, public programs, and community-driven art. These spaces celebrate the beauty of place and the untold stories of what are often overlooked and misrepresented communities. 

I am particularly inspired by:

Life is Living Festival in Oakland, which brings alive the the Black Panther legacy of community resilience and service through an art and music festival that sparks dialogue around community health and environmental issues. All this happens in deFremery Park, the very location where the revolutionary group held forth 50 years ago. The park becomes a living testament to the soulful Oakland identity that has overcome adversity by staying true to its legacy  while continuing to invent itself.

Image via: youthspeaks.org

POW! WOW! Hawaii beautifies neighborhoods in Honolulu with vibrant murals based on local themes— and invites the community to participate in the creative process. An example of the art you may find is a contemporary mural interpretation of King Kalakaua, bringing a rich legacy of Hawaiian royalty, resistance, and sovereignty to the urban streets for all to experience and be empowered by.

Image via: powwowhawaii.com

East Coast Land Art Festival In Taitung, Taiwan, artists strengthen the community's relationship to the land and honor indigenous traditions through creating large-scale, immersive artworks deeply tied to the ecology of the island's pristine East Coast.


THE IMPACT

Ours is a time marked by great innovation and prosperity— alongside salient injustices. Economic inequality exists. Communities of color, immigrant, and indigenous communities continue to be marginalized through disconnection and disenfranchisement— to each other, to the environment, to visibility of positive self images.

In the midst of these inequities, there are visionary artists and community leaders who acknowledge the challenges and see opportunity. They look beyond struggle and embrace the ways communities are thriving. They see over-looked and under-resourced spaces and see possibility for creating something new. 

These creatives, in collaboration with their communities, are transforming under-resourced spaces into meaningful places of culture, expression, inquiry, and connection by activating space with dynamic art and public programs. This practice could also be thought of as creative placemaking. By activating space with art and culture, these locations transform into meaningful places that strengthen communities and make visible the resilience and cultural resources that are already present. 

We see empowered, engaged communities; positive youth development; strengthened sense of place, identity, belonging, stewardship; and positive social change catalyzed.

ABOUT ME

I am a San Francisco native, a daughter of immigrants, a global citizen, critical thinker and lifelong learner, infinitely curious about the role art, culture, and design have on catalyzing positive social change and the ways we can design better cities that are inclusive, equitable, healthy, and vibrant places to live for all people. 

I currently apply my critical thinking and curiosity to my role as producer and strategist with An Otherwise Co., a women-led design collective, partnering with Bay Area-based social changemakers in their creative communications projects.

As a cultural thinker and program designer, I want to shine a light on these movements of art and public space, and explore how artists and community leaders are catalyzing positive social impact. I have traveled from Bahia, Brazil to Kaohsiung, Taiwan. From New Orleans to Brooklyn— practicing empathy, valuing human connection, honoring local traditions, always observing the ways communities find strength in culture and create space for art. 

These experiences have catapulted me into a desire to continue traveling and seeing the world in a transformative way. Next stop: the MTP trail in search of the artists committed to building strong communities through art and culture and explore how we can make more of this happen in the places that need it the most.


UNCOMMON SPACES x MILLENNIAL TRAINS 

A 10-day railroad journey across America with stops in cities like Pittsburgh, Chicago, Kansas City, Albuquerque, and Los Angeles, Millennial Trains Project is a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to travel cross-country by railroad, and connect deeply with what urban communities are making possible. Along the way, I’ll gain access to world class mentors, leadership development, design thinking skills, and an incredible opportunity to grow as a leader and innovator— I will come away from the experience poised to lead positive change in my San Francisco Bay Area community. 

I am using the MTP journey as a platform to investigate and gain an understanding of each city through the lens of  art, place, and community: 

  • What are the changes, challenges, and conditions that communities are facing? 
  • How are artists and leaders addressing those challenges in creative ways? 
  • What are the practices, processes, and theories of change faced by creative placemakers and visionary artists as they endeavor to build strong, diverse, empowered communities through their creative activations? 
  • How are the stories, dreams, triumphs, and challenges of these communities expressed through these projects? 
  • What can I share from my observations and experiences in the SF Bay Area that can support communities across the country?

Demographics in America are shifting, and I am placing particular focus on communities of color that have often been disenfranchised from resources, investment, and processes of urban planning and arts funding— yet it is these very communities that will drive growth and change.

These are communities on the verge— and through the MTP journey, I’ll get to curate content for Uncommon Spaces while investigating community-driven creative placemaking on one of the two Millennial Train Journeys happening this summer.

But I need your support! While my project has been shortlisted by the MTP Selection Committee, it's up to my community to get me all the way through. I need to be among the first 30 applicants to crowd fund the $5000 program fee to secure my spot on the train, and your support will help me achieve that. 

Your contribution is a tax-deductible donation to Millennial Trains Project, a 501(c)3 non-profit and it gets me on board one of these two journeys that are being offered through the Millennial Trains Project. I've researched and identified the following organizations in each city from which I will curate content for the Uncommon Spaces website. Let me know if there are other great organizations in these cities that I can connect with!

"CHANGE"  // August 1-7

PITTSBURGH: City of Asylum and Pittsburgh Cultural Trust

CHICAGO: Arts in Public Life Initiative

KANSAS CITY: Arts Council of Johnson County

ALBUQUERQUE: Stories of Route 66: The International District

LOS ANGELES: Manifest:Justice

"UNITY" // August 10-17

LOS ANGELES: Manifest:Justice

SAN FRANCISCO: Quesada Gardens Initiative and Mission Community Market

DENVER: RedLine Art Space and Birdseed Collective

MILWAUKEE: The ARTery

DETROIT: Porous Borders Festival

A note on funding:

  • If this campaign is among the first 30 to reach its $5K goal, all funds raised will go to Millennial Trains Project, which is a 501(c)3 organization. Any donation you make will be tax-deductible. 
  • Your donation will help to underwrite the costs of the journey and its associated programming, transportation, and hospitality fees. 
  • If I am not not among the first 30 applicants to reach my crowdfunding goal, you will not be charged for your donation.

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

Now, I know not all of us are rollin in it and in a position to make a monetary contribution. And there are other ways you can support me that would be just as meaningful! 

  • Share the campaign. Post this link to Facebook to get the word out to friends and networks >>

    http://igg.me/at/uncommon-spaces/x/1643098

  • If you know about any Uncommon Spaces happening in your community that my project can bring shine to, please share!

story:
The Lady Sassafras: Funking Up The Playa Since 2008

The Playa is just around the corner and while we've been working at getting the Lady Sass in tip top cruising shape, we've got a few hurdles to navigate to get her going as well as some things on our wish list to make her even more awesome.

  1. Sad to report that the 6500W generator that you all helped us purchase during our 2013 campaign has been stolen.  We need to replace this in order to bring on the groove.
  2. There are a host of mechanical repairs and esthetic issues with her this year.  She needs some lovin' y'all!
  3. It has been 8 years since we brought the Lady Sass to BRC for the first time.  We figure it's time for her to have a psychedelic makeover.  She's getting a professional full lighting upgrade!!!!!  We'll finally be able to pick out her shape in the evening as she slowly cruises across the Playa.  

If you love the Lady Sassafras, and want to continue dancing to her Funky Sounds, please donate and help us keep the Funk alive! Shake what your Mama gave ya'!!!!!!

If you love the Lady Sassafras, and want to continue dancing to her Funky Sounds, please donate and help us keep the Funk alive! Shake what your Mama gave ya'!!!!!!

story:
Hi. My name is Casey.

I'm a Buffalo born artist and designer, and I'm on a mission to create an iconic "Greetings from Buffalo" mural that our whole city will be proud of. As I've traveled, I've seen tourists in places like Austin, TX flocking to snap photos in front of the beloved "Greetings from Austin" mural. Other cities like Chicago, Cleveland, and Detroit have caught on to this trend, too. With tourism soaring and murals going up all over Buffalo, this is the perfect time to create our own version to welcome visitors to the Queen City. 

For three weeks in August, you'll see me transform this brick wall outside of the Washington Market into one of the most colorful murals in the city. Check out this before and after!

My concept for the mural is "City on the Rise," and nothing captures that idea quite like the sunburst stained glass ceiling inside City Hall’s Common Council Chamber. That place has always inspired me, and I've used the pattern of the ceiling as the backdrop for my mural. Colorful letters that spell "Buffalo" will pop off the mural just like an old fashioned postcard. All while a red Buffalo proudly steps outside of the mural, ready to check out all of the new and exciting things happening in our city today.

SO, HERE'S WHERE I'M AT

  • I've already found the perfect wall and I have the green light from the owner of the building to begin the project. It'll be located right in the heart of downtown outside of the Washington Market.
  • The Niagara Distilling Company (the Market's neighbor) has granted me access to their driveway to paint the mural. Thank's y'all!
  • I've already set aside three weeks in August to complete the mural. 
  • I have a proven track record of running a successful, Buffalo-inspired Indiegogo Campaign. Check out my campaign for CityHEART — a heart-shaped bicycle sculpture that I made three summers ago.
  • This summer, I've done quite a bit of research on exterior murals. I even chatted with a few local mural artists who gave me some great advice. Thanks Bruce Adams and Kimberly Halavin!
  • Visit Buffalo Niagara has seen my design and they love it! (Check out their testimonial below). 
  • Visit Buffalo Niagara has also agreed to help me distribute free, limited edition postcards of the mural once it's complete. Now proud Buffalonians can send postcards to friends all over the world, just like people did during the Queen City's heyday!

THE PERKS

To help reach my funding goal of $6,500 I've created a bunch of Buffalo-inspired perks for you! 

Have you always wanted an 11 x 14 print of my popular City Hall illustration? Or maybe a giant version of my one of my Buffalo drawings blown up and wheat pasted on your wall, just like I did inside EXPO Market? These are just a few examples of the perks I'm offering right now. And, in the weeks ahead, I'll be offering a handful of exclusive LOCAL ONLY perks, so check back often and keep an eye out for my campaign updates. 

My goal is to use my art to create reasonably priced perks to get this mural funded. Every donation I receive helps me pay for the cleaning and prepping of the wall, high quality paint supplies (so the mural will last a very long time), artist's insurance, equipment rental, scissor lift rental, and anti-graffiti sealers. Your support also allows me to dedicate three weeks of my time to finish this mural. 

"Greetings from Buffalo" Mural Schedule

Week #1: Cleaning and prepping the wall, sanding old paint off the wall, and filling in holes with mortar compound. I'll also be sealing the existing brick wall in preparation of the primer coats and then priming the mural area. 

Week #2: Drawing mural outlines onto the wall with graphite, and then painting and filling in the final colors.

Week #3: Touch up of the final colors, spray on 2-3 layers of anti-graffiti coating, and final photography. 

HOW CAN YOU HELP?

DONATE. SHARE. SPREAD THE BUFFALOVE.

A little BUFFALOVE goes a long way! 

THIS IS WHAT VISIT BUFFALO NIAGARA HAD TO SAY...

"Having seen similar murals in other cities around the country and the social media posts they’ve generated, Visit Buffalo Niagara is thrilled that local artist Casey Milbrand is going to be creating a Greetings from Buffalo mural. Not only will this new mural make the emerging restaurant row along Ellicott Street a more vibrant and visually appealing destination, it will contribute to Buffalo’s public art renaissance and our city’s presence online. Murals are a big part of an engaging urban landscape and Casey’s contribution is sure to make downtown Buffalo an even more stimulating experience for visitors — one we’re sure they’ll share with friends and family via Facebook, Instagram and Twitter. If you want to be a part of the New Buffalo we urge you to make a contribution to Casey’s Indiegogo campaign." — Visit Buffalo Niagara

story:
Hey! I'm Bubbleknight. Thanks for checking out my enamel pin project, RPG Classy Class Pins!

I've been a tabletop/RPG fan for years and want to create some hard enamel pins to show my love and appreciation for that genre! I typically make chibi/cute pins and creating these breaks out of my typical norm with designs. I hope you still enjoy them!

My previous pin projects, KAWAII TO KOWAI - Cute & Scary Japanese Lore and Classic Creatures Enamel Pins, were successful! Thank you, everyone, who showed interest and made those campaigns a wonderful reality.

I am currently anticipating 50 pieces per design (lower quantity to make sure I can get as many designs as possible for this collection), but will order more if necessary.

Three designs have already been created, but will remain a part of this project and are considered unlocked! Barbarian, Sorcerer, and Bard.

  • Each hard enamel pin will be gold plated with black and white enamel
  • Roughly 40mm (~1.58")
  • Two posts on back with black rubber clutches

The first goal will fund the Ranger, Rogue, Warlock, and Cleric pins.

My hope is to create and unlock a total of 15 designs based off class symbols:

  • Barbarian
  • Sorcerer
  • Bard
  • Ranger
  • Rogue
  • Warlock
  • Cleric
  • Wizard
  • Druid
  • Fighter
  • Monk
  • Paladin
  • Artificer
  • Blood Hunter
  • Dungeon Master (not a class, but the role is very important to each campaign!)



I have received pictures of my first three designs that have been created as examples for what the final product will look like:

 

Additional stretch goals will be added as more pins become unlocked.

Risks & Challenges:

I have been selling products online and shipping since 2012. I'm familiar with online sales, researching and reaching out to various manufacturers for creating new products.

Line thickness may be altered slightly with the final physical design. Colors may also appear different due to monitor settings.

Changes in manufacturing time may happen, such as delays during production or corrections in final product, but I'll give updates ASAP whenever it occurs!
story_txt:
Hey! I'm Bubbleknight. Thanks for checking out my enamel pin project, RPG Classy Class Pins!I've been a tabletop/RPG fan for years and want to create some hard enamel pins to show my love and appreciation for that genre! I typically make chibi/cute pins and creating these breaks out of my typical norm with designs. I hope you still enjoy them!My previous pin projects, KAWAII TO KOWAI - Cute & Scary Japanese Lore and Classic Creatures Enamel Pins, were successful! Thank you, everyone, who showed interest and made those campaigns a wonderful reality.I am currently anticipating 50 pieces per design (lower quantity to make sure I can get as many designs as possible for this collection), but will order more if necessary.Three designs have already been created, but will remain a part of this project and are considered unlocked! Barbarian, Sorcerer, and Bard.
Each hard enamel pin will be gold plated with black and white enamel
Roughly 40mm (~1.58")
Two posts on back with black rubber clutches
The first goal will fund the Ranger, Rogue, Warlock, and Cleric pins.My hope is to create and unlock a total of 15 designs based off class symbols:
Barbarian
Sorcerer
Bard
Ranger
Rogue
Warlock
Cleric
Wizard
Druid
Fighter
Monk
Paladin
Artificer
Blood Hunter
Dungeon Master (not a class, but the role is very important to each campaign!)
