story:
Friends,

The Cathouse is a performance/art space that can accommodate somewhere in the vicinity of 40-45 people comfortably for various events. It is home to William Benton, Sarah Summerwell, and David Cundiff, but William operates the lower half of the building as a community/art space.

In the past*, The Cathouse hosted live musical performances, poetry readings, community meetings, art shows, and film screenings.

While the current (re)occupants are very happy to be (back) in The Cathouse and hosting a variety of special events, due to the cost of relocation and some unfortunate events of late, we are reaching out to friends to see if we can keep the improvements on track.

Things we are looking to do:

1.) Sound dampening. The main room is big and boomy which works well for some things but not so well for others. We want to place sound dampening materials strategically throughout the main room to make it a more suitable performance space for all performers.

2.) Sound. We have a modest PA with two monitors which gets the job nearly done, but, we aspire to get two "mains" to project better. If the goal amount is achieved then we will likely upgrade the entire system.

3.) Paint. We would like to black out a few walls to make it more accommodating for small theatrical rehearsals and performances. (Eventually, we would like to convert the smaller back room into a visual art gallery which will require some painting, lighting, etc- but that is a ways out.)

4. ) Bills. It's very difficult to warm the downstairs area (the entire building, actually) and, as we are just starting, it has been a real bite into the budget to turn that furnace on. We would like to always maintain a fund to keep that a not-so-prevalent worry. This fund would also be in place for inevitable maintenance issues that will surely arise as we use the space.

5.) Seating. We would like to host seated events and, therefore, require a collection of folding chairs.

6.) Rugs. We have a great floor now in the performance space but would like some large rugs for making it more comfortable, would likely help with sound, and would help with temperature control during cold weather.

7.) A riser. We would like to build a small, sectional stage that can be moved around to wherever performers want it to be.

8.) Projector upgrade. Our projector is old and could crater at any time. It is important to us to be able to show films and project visuals for various events.

9.) Internet. Yeah, we don't have internet yet.


*William Benton started The Cathouse as such a few years back. Following his departure, it was inherited by Brad Anderson, and is now back in the hands of Mr. Benton, his girlfriend Sarah, and his brother, David.


#cathouseky #catcasual #louisvillemusic

story:
Todos sabemos que debajo de la cama viven monstruos, lo que poca gente conoce es que estos monstruos se llaman Alicuencanitos. No son feos, no muerden, y no intentarán asustarte. Normalmente se conforman con merendar pelusas y esconderte las zapatillas, pero también les gusta la compañía y salir de debajo de la cama. Recuerda asomarte y saludarles siempre que puedas.
 

 

 

Este proyecto empezó como una forma de aplicar ilustración a producto, de manera artesanal y hecha a mano. Poco a poco fue tomando forma, pero la falta de tiempo y presupuesto obligó a "parar" el proyecto, ya que con pocos recursos resultaba desbordante e inasumible.

Básicamente, la cifra que se pretende alcanzar se dedicará a 3 objetivos:

  • Fabricación de los muñecos (producto principal). Los prototipos y primeros muñecos a la venta se han estado realizando en sarga de algodón impresa y posteriormente cosida. El resultado es un muñeco con todo lujo de detalles, 100% ecológico, seguro para los más pequeños, y por supuesto, blandito y adorable!
  • Packaging. O lo que es lo mismo, embalaje de cada producto para su venta.
  • Productos alternativos. Calcomanías, láminas, material de papelería, accesorios, bolsos... la magia de este proyecto es que ofrece infinitas posibilidades, al fin y al cabo, todo comenzó aplicando una ilustración a un producto. ¡Expansión!
  • ¡Gastos aburridos! Pero igualmente necesarios. Comenzar cualquier actividad de este tipo requiere una serie de gastos burocráticos lamentablemente ineludibles.

 

 

 

Te presento a los Alicuencanitos:

 

El primero. El clásico. El primogénito. Habichuela vive debajo de la cama y se alimenta de pelusas. Tiene cierta tendencia a la cleptomanía de calzado, especialmente zapatillas de cuadros y franela, que son sus favoritas. Hace años, un verano, descubrió que no tenía ombligo y se puso triste. Salvo ese momento, siempre ha sido el Alicuencanito más feliz y con menos dientes de todos.

El único Alicuencanito volador, que no vive bajo la cama, ya que es alérgico a las pelusas. Calabaza prefiere el aire libre durante el día, y duerme en los armarios por las noches, siempre y cuando estén lo suficientemente desordenados como para sentirse cómodo. Cree que puede camuflarse entre las lámparas de Ikea, pero no.

Con sus cuatro patas, Galleta es un portento del fútbol alicuencanil. Compagina su trabajo de jugador profesional con el de balón de reglamento. En sus ratos libres juega a la petanca. Es algo corto de vista, pero demasiado presumido para usar sus tres monóculos.

Cuentan que el señor Wilson es un emigrante gallego, originalmente llamado Eulogio Pazos, que se dedica al extraperlo de percebes y licor café. Ahora vive sus días de retiro en Inglaterra, acompañado de su mujer Margaret. Perdió las cejas en el año 43, combatiendo en la guerra cuando tan sólo era un joven cojín de trinchera.

Espera... ¿sólo esos?

¡Claro que no! Alicuencanitos hay tantos como camas en el mundo, evidentemente. Tendréis que buscarlos, si se dejan.

Aparte de los cuatro que ya conocéis, hay otros que han cedido sus derechos de imagen para este proyecto:

Mrs. Margaret, señora de Wilson, toda una artista del macramé con pelusas, y profesora de la escuela alicuencanil. Menta y Arándano son sus dos únicos alumnos, el primero y el último de la clase, respectivamente. Y por último, Dumb. Es un alicuencanito.... especial. Hay que quererlo.

 

     

     

 

Todos los muñecos están fabricados en sarga de algodón 100%, posteriormente impresa con tintas ecológicas, cosida, y rellena con fibras también de algodón natural.

El proceso, hoy por hoy hecho a mano, es tedioso y caro. El principal objetivo es poder asumir una fabricación de mayor volumen, de manera que sea posible encargar la manufactura a artesanos/fabricantes locales. De esa forma sería posible atender pedidos de una manera más lógica y abaratar los costes (tanto de producción, como el precio final del producto).

 

 

Hemos probado con tazas, mochilas, calcomanías (tattoos), peluches gigantes, camisetas... nuevos personajes, e infinidad de nuevas ideas. Las posibilidades son casi infinitas! Y nos encanta seguir creando y experimentando. O al menos, nos encantaría poder hacerlo.

 

 

 

 

A ti, que has llegado hasta aquí. Quizá en este punto pienses, "por qué no, voy a colaborar!". Genial. Para empezar tienes todo mi agradecimiento, y espero firmemente que los dioses de tu elección te den una vida feliz llena de chocolate, gatos e hijos. O lo que prefieras. Aún así, de una manera más tangible, te ofrezco lo siguiente:

  • Donando 1€. Lámina digital. Elige entre varios tamaños/formatos, y úsala como más te guste! De fondo de escritorio, en tu móvil, imprímela...
  • Donando 5€. Set de calcomanías/tattoos, a elegir entre varios modelos.
  • Donando 10€. Una taza de tu alicuencanito favorito. Varios modelos e ilustraciones a elegir.
  • Donando 15€. Un alicuencanito! Auténtico. Blandito. Achuchable. Tú eliges cuál.
  • Donando 20€. Un alicuencanito + set de calcomanías.
  • Donando 20€. Un bolso de asa (shopping bag, para los entendidos).
  • Donando 20€. Un bolso saco, tipo mochila.
  • Donando 20€. Una taza portátil, con tapa, para que puedas llevarla donde quieras.
  • Donando 25€. Un alicuencanito + una taza.
  • Donando 25€. Una sudadera de capucha.
  • Donando 30€. Dos alicuencanitos.
  • Donando 30€. Un alicuencanitos y una camiseta.
  • Donando 60€. La familia al completo.
  • Donando 100€. Familia al completo + set de calcomanías + set de tazas.

 

 

 

*Ningún Alicuencanito fue maltratado en la realización de este proyecto,

story:
Veterans commit 20% of suicides in the United States. However, veterans only make up 1% of our total population.  My name is Richard Casper, and I can relate to veterans who are burdened by things they have seen or done during war.  I have been able to cope with my war-related issues through art, and would like to help other veterans do the same.  Please help me introduce art into the lives of people who do not have outlets for their problems…I believe art can help save them.

I am a disabled veteran and who was injured while deployed in Iraq in 2006 and 2007. When I came home I realized I brought with me problems that I did not know how to deal with: anxiety, depression, and a disconnect from normal life. I tried to better myself through the Veterans Hospital and other therapies, but nothing was working for me. It wasn’t until I started taking art classes at the local community college that I discovered art could help me. I now attend one of the best art schools in the country.

I truly believe that art can heal. One can take whatever pain is inside of himself and put it into clay, on paper, or canvas. I have better control over my disabilities and thoughts when I’m creating artwork. Give other veterans that same chance at a better life through art.

 

The money raised will go to provide:

 

  • The classroom to gather and make art 
  • Transportation of veterans from the nearest veterans hospital
  • The cost of the clay
  • The cost of the kiln rental and firings
  • Glazes for clay
  • Paints
  • Brushes 
  • Canvas

 

The Impact

 

The impact of this program will be lives bettered, and possibly lives saved through art.  Veterans need an outlet for many issues they may come home with.  For me, there is no better outlet than art, and I believe other veterans can discover the same if they have the opportunity.  Non-veterans will be impacted by this program as well since they will get to experience any works that veteran artists would like to display.  The art can be thought-provoking and eye opening through the stories it will tell of the veterans’ experiences.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

 

  • Get the word out and make some noise about this campaign.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!
  • Tell everyone to help support veterans in any way they can.

I am a disabled veteran and who was injured while deployed in Iraq in 2006 and 2007. When I came home I realized I brought with me problems that I did not know how to deal with: anxiety, depression, and a disconnect from normal life. I tried to better myself through the Veterans Hospital and other therapies, but nothing was working for me. It wasn’t until I started taking art classes at the local community college that I discovered art could help me. I now attend one of the best art schools in the country.
I truly believe that art can heal. One can take whatever pain is inside of himself and put it into clay, on paper, or canvas. I have better control over my disabilities and thoughts when I’m creating artwork. Give other veterans that same chance at a better life through art.
 
The money raised will go to provide:
 

The classroom to gather and make art 
Transportation of veterans from the nearest veterans hospital
The cost of the clay
The cost of the kiln rental and firings
Glazes for clay
Paints
Brushes 
Canvas

 
The Impact
 
The impact of this program will be lives bettered, and possibly lives saved through art.  Veterans need an outlet for many issues they may come home with.  For me, there is no better outlet than art, and I believe other veterans can discover the same if they have the opportunity.  Non-veterans will be impacted by this program as well since they will get to experience any works that veteran artists would like to display.  The art can be thought-provoking and eye opening through the stories it will tell of the veterans’ experiences.
 
Other Ways You Can Help
 

Get the word out and make some noise about this campaign.
Use the Indiegogo share tools!
Tell everyone to help support veterans in any way they can.

story:
Since July 2013 we have been busy working to redevelop a 3000 sq. foot warehouse unit into a multifunctional artist run space - we have come far, but now we need your help to make our vision happen.

We are Lacuna Crux - a collective of twelve artists from the UK and Bahrain - recent graduates of the University of the West of England, Bristol. Our project, Building Loft 6D, is the beginning of a collaborative partnership that will allow each of us to flourish in a variety of creative fields, both individually and together. Loft 6D will initially function as a base for Lacuna Crux to make and show work and projects within. In time Loft 6D will provide a platform for other creatives to use through residencies, workshops, exhibitions, discussions, film screenings, spoken word events ... The possibilities are endless ... But first we need get the place up to scratch.

Sustaining the momentum and critical engagement we developed throughout our time together at university is vital to our growth as artists and creative professionals. Individually we are passionate and driven and together even more so. Over the past eleven months we have worked persistently to alter and re-build the space according to our plans, deconstructing the pre-existing internal framework, upgrading and re-fitting the electrics and plumbing, building studio spaces and a gallery wall. So far this has been done out of our own pockets, using our own skills. It has been a huge development but one that will only be bettered by progressing with the next stages of the build.

Your monetary support will be used to fund the build of two necessary structures. The first is the fabrication area, which will house facilities enabling both ourselves and others to work in a variety of processes that are crucial to our practices, safely and efficiently; including wood, metal, ceramics, wax, enamelling, resins .... The list goes on. The second is to build sets of modular stud walls, which will allow us to create pop-up individual studio/project spaces within Loft 6D. So far have had interest from artists looking for space for: building/making work, photography space, crit/meeting space, rehearsal space - we are keen to support as many creative activities as possible in Loft 6D!

Our projected aim is to make Loft 6D available to creatives by running workshops and providing an associates programme so that others may benefit from the facilities. Firstly we have to build the fabrication area and the modular stud walls so that we can deliver these intentions successfully.

Thank you for your time and support. Through pledging you will receive not only a gift as a token of our thanks but you will be supporting the creation of a new and much needed creative project in this area.


Please check out our external Links HERE:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Zwqx3yrcNOc


More to be added soon.......

story:
My Story

Konichiwa!  My name is Linda and I want to go to Japan.  For the past three years I have taken on an early morning paper route so I could pay my bills while attending Boise State University pursuing a BFA Visual Arts - Photography emphasis degree.  As part of that program, I now have the opportunity to participate in an International exhibit through the Nagoya Zokei University in Japan.

I will have the opportunity to spend two weeks in Japan exhibiting my work at the Nagoya Zokei University while participating in workshops with other art and design students.  While there we will also have the opportunity to visit art museums and conduct field trips related to various art and design disciplines of Japan including paper making, textiles, ceramics, and landscape design.  As well as seeing Nagoya and the surrounding area, we will also visit Kyoto, visiting temples and gardens.

The trip is slated for June 8 - 23.

The Impact

It's hard to say what kind of an impact this will have on my life.  I do know, it will not be the same as it is today.  This will help launch the career I have always dreamed of.  For you, you'll know that you've supported the arts, helped me become better at my craft and have also assisted in making a dream come true for me.

What I Need & What You Get

I need to raise enough money to cover everything for this trip.  Unfortunately, a paper route salary is not even enough to meet basic needs. There is nothing left over to plan a trip.  Costs will cover tuition, airfare, meals, event tickets, ground transportation, and lodging, as well as cover a substitute paper carrier in my absence.  There again, a paper carrier at the Idaho Statesman is not allowed a "vacation."  The paper must be delivered 7 days a week, 365 days a year.  International Learning Opportunities is providing scholarships to each student participant of $1300.  This will help greatly in reducing the cost, but it is still expensive.

You can help get me there by supporting this campaign with a contribution of whatever size.  Anything will bring me one step closer. 

If you've read this far, I already send my deepest gratitude.  If you decide to donate, look to the right to see perks offered. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Needless to say, SPREAD THE WORD!  Please share this campaign every day on Facebook, Twitter, or anywhere you spend your time to get the word out and make some noise about my "International Learning Opportunity." 

And, use the share tools provided by IndiGoGo to get other folks in-the-know.  Thank you so much.

story:
WoCA's INDEMAND!

As a funded project of Indiegogo, WoCA's Art in Community Programs campaign is now participating in Indiegogo's InDemand program--that is, our Art in Community programs campaign will continue to receive contributions!

As some of you know, as of January 2015, we recently moved from our then location on Race Street, and are in the process of moving to a new space. Nonetheless, through our community partners like the TCU Art Galleries and many other organizations, we are thrilled to be in the planning stages of many of our community arts programs!

Within the next few months we will begin disbursing links and information about our campaign perks, starting with a virtual tour of our 2nd Annual Juried Artist's Books Exhibition!

We are grateful to the individuals and organizations that have given to our campaign through our fiscal sponsorship with Fractured Atlas even after the campaign ended. Fractured Atlas is the best way to give to our campaign if you would like your contribution to be tax-deductible.

We are well on our way everyone! Great partnerships are popping up left and right and we are so excited! Looking forward to sharing new official updates with you.

If you know someone who didn't have the opportunity to contribute to our campaign urge them to give now! #WoCAinCommunity #InDemand
https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/art-in-community-programs-at-woca-projects/x/2813367

___________________________________________________________________________

#GivingTuesday Update!!

As we approach #GivingTuesday and we are nearly passed our goal (raising a whopping 99% in less than a week!). Help us to raise a new goal of $5000 to double our efforts in the local community by bringing even more arts-making activities into the community and funding for more opportunities to impact our women in our community through arts-based entrepreneurship.

We have made such great progress in less than a week! Imagine what we can accomplish by December 22nd (the end of our campaign). Let's do even more! #GivingTuesday is only two days away so let's not only double our efforts for #GivingTuesday but keep pushing to enhance these programs. We have 23 more days until the campaign ends. So let's work together!

Double our efforts AND you will

--Help us to fund another $250 in art supplies/materials to teach ongoing art/making classes with local children.

--Help to raise another $500 for our Young Curators Program to take young women ages 13-17 to another regional museum.

--Help us raise another $1000 toward support our Creative Entrepreneurship program.

--Help us to raise another $250 to hire 2-3 more artists to teach art classes.

--And help us to give another $500 grant to a local artists of color in the DFW area!

Short Summary

WoCA Projects is a non-profit artspace that highlights the works of women artists of color and artists of all backgrounds through exhibitions, and creates opportunities for the local community to become engaged in art through our community arts programs. WoCA Projects was founded in February 2013 by local Fort Worth artist, Lauren Cross, and since its opening has featured amazing exhibtions and art programs to the local community.

Beginning on #GivingTuesday, WoCA Projects is raising funds to develop new, ongoing community arts programs for children, youth, and adults in the local Greater Fort Worth community. In a world where funds for art programs are continuously dwindling for the communities that need them the most, WoCA Projects would like to create more opportunities to serve children, youth, and adults in our local community. Community citizens who don't typically have access to art-making opportunities, and allow the community to have a voice in participating in creative approaches for social and cultural change.

What We Need 

By giving to our #GivingTuesday campaign you will help WoCA to create and bring innovative art programs to the local Fort Worth community that are relevant to the lives of local citizens in need of art education and creative development. Your contribution of $25 could help us to raise some of these programming budget goals:

1. $250 worth of art supplies/materials to teach ongoing art-making classes and workshops to children from low to moderate income families both in our WoCA facility and in partnership with local community groups and organizations. 

2. $500 to take a group of 15 young women, ages 13-17, on a trip to a local museum for WoCA's Young Art Curators Program: a program developed for young women ages 13-17  to be taught, trained, and given opportunities to explore careers in art/curating/exhibition-making. We hope to offer the program at little to no cost so your contribution will helps us to do it!

3. $1000 to begin a Creative Entrepreneurship program, which invests creative skill development and entrepreneurship training into 10-15 adult women in the local community to create their own supplemental income (i.e., art, jewelry-making, sewing, fashion, home/body products, etc), to fight poverty, and to help develop the local creative economy. The program will support participants by teaching skills in product development, marketing/communications, packaging/display, online store development, and allow participants to sell their products in the WoCA Projects a new WoCA Gift Shop, and at local hand-made market events.

4. $250 Hire to 2-3 teaching artists/creatives to offer affordable courses/workshops to the local community and to support our programs.

5. $500 to offer a modest artist material grant of up to $500 to a local Dallas/Fort Worth artist of color so that they can create new, innovative artwork.

Our #GivingTuesday campaign goal is to raise $2500, which would allow us to fund all of the programs listed above. So the more we raise the more we can do! We are starting with one modest funding goal to support a variety of different projects in hopes that we will build support from the global community to keep these diverse programs going and refine them for the future. So help WoCA make a difference through art and creative practice! 

What You Get

Not only will your contributions make positive change in the local community but we offer perks that allow you to play a unique role in our community-- be the change you'd want to see! Our perk is to create opportunities for contributors to join our community of artists and local citizens, who love art or know that art can create positive change, and encourage you to be a part of our initiative in fun and meaningful ways. Join us and you'll gain an experience and a connection with art! Here are a list of some of our cool and empowering perks:

- Take a Interactive Group Tour w/WoCA Founder/Director

- Express Your Own Creativity Through Art-Making Activities

- Engage in New Learning Experiences

- Directly Impact Our Programs Through Your Ideas!

Just think...these perks are just the beginning. Not only will your contribution support our programs but enables you to be an active participant in positive community development and change! 

If We Don't Reach Our Entire Goal

If we don't reach our goal, WoCA will still receive all funds that were raised; however, not raising our funding goal will limit the range of programs that we would like to offer. We want to be able to offer all of our programs, but we understand that sometimes budget does not allow us to. This is why we intentionally created contribution levels that match specific program needs so that if you are passionate about getting a certain program off the ground you can be a major contributor to that effort and make sure that it happens. This way, Groups/Businesses/Organizations might choose to come together and support and fund a specific program. So if the entire funding goal is not reached we at least are able to bring certain programs that funders felt passionate about to fruition. 

If all funds are not raised and specific programs are not funded we will begin with the smallest funding goals and build from there (i.e., if we raise $500 we will be able to fund $250 worth of art supplies/materials to teach art-making classes to children in the local community and $250 to hire 2 to 3 teaching artists to teach workshops to the local community and to support our programs. Not bad for $500 raised!)

The Impact

This #GivingTuesday campaign will allow us to make a considerable impact in our local community by creating art programs that empower creative change and experiences. Your contribution will:

  • Not only supports our initiative but allow you to be a change-maker in our community not just by your contribution but as an active participant in the lives of the people we hope to touch. 
  • Spark creative action and help to build the local creative economy.
  • Encourage local communities to participate in more art-making activities and support a greater attention to building community through art.
In 2014, WoCA offered some really exciting art-making activities and programs that were connected to our featured art exhibitions. In 2015, our community arts program initiatives hope to reach beyond our exhibitions and create ongoing opportunities for the local community to benefit socially, culturally, and economically from our programs. We have already begun to partner with some local community groups and organizations that will allow us to accomplish our program initiatives and objectives. All we need is the funding to kick these programs off the ground. 
Your contribution will help us to make a positive impact in the local community through the arts!

Risks & Challenges

We are aware that the programs we are trying to initiate in 2015 are ambitious! We have high goals and expectations for what art can accomplish in our local community.  We are driven by recent feedback from within the local community about how we can better serve the community through our programs. Please take heart! We will not be beginning these programs alone. We have many organizations and individuals in the local community that have already agreed to partner and volunteer and help us with our vision, and as we kick off these programs we will continue to seek community imput on how to best perfect our programs through: 

- focus groups, interviews, and surveys to help evaluate or programs and strengthen them for future participants. 

- partnering with local community leaders, groups and organizations with similar missions and goals to become involved and strengthen our program objectives.

- document our program outcomes and share with the community and with you!

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that everyone is not able to contribute financially. Here are some other ways to support our project(s):

  • Please spread the word to your local network and make some noise about our campaign! If you have a blog... blog about us. If you have Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, post about our campaign on your platform. Send an email. Write a letter. Make a video. Create art!
  • Use hashtags: Use #GivingTuesday when sharing on December 2nd and #WoCACommunity2015 when posting about our campaign on social media.
  • Use Indiegogo's share tools, then tag and retweet to build momentum!
  • Volunteer to serve on our marketing team. Send an to info@wocaprojects.com if you are interested.
  • Host a fundraising party at home with food and drinks with friends, family, co-workers, and networks. Send us a message at info@wocaprojects.com and we can show you how to do it!

Thank you in advance for supporting WoCA on #GivingTuesday, December 2nd, 2014!
